title: Allison Payne
text:
Hi there!
I’m a PhD candidate in the Beltran Lab at UC Santa Cruz.
My current projects use long-term demographic datasets, passive acoustics, and bio-logging to study the ecology of marine predators. Read more about my research, or explore my individual projects.

title: Allison Payne
text:
I’m a PhD student in the Beltran Lab at UC Santa Cruz interested in utilizing long-term ecological data sets for conservation.
My current projects focus on demography, passive acoustics, and bio-logging. I’m passionate about inclusive teaching, mentoring/publishing with undergraduates, and science facilitation practices.

title: Queer Ecologies
text:
Aspen Ellis and I first designed and taught our course, titled Queer Ecologies, in spring 2023. This class was a seminar style undergraduate course designed to expand students’ horizons, incorporate diverse perspectives into the existing curriculum, and build community. We’re thrilled to be offering the class again in spring 2024.
Don’t miss checking out our students’ incredible Unessay1 projects here!

title: Open Biologging Project
text:
Read about our efforts to review the state of open science for biologging on the project website.
This review is led by Dr. Max Czapanskiy (with help from many other amazing co-authors). Join the review team and help us out!

title: Anti-Harassment Workshops
text:
I am the Director of Facilitation for FieldFutures, an organization that delivers workshops for groups of field scientists. The workshops are interactive and address the unique concerns of remote fieldwork.
We recently evaluated the efficacy of the workshop through a collaboration with a state agency. Read the manuscript here and a news bulletin here.

title: Queer & Trans Inclusive Fieldwork Summit
text:
I received a Beyond Compliance grant from UC Santa Cruz to host a small group of UC faculty, postdocs, and grad students who do ecological field research for one weekend at Blue Oak Ranch Reserve. Our goals were to build community, share resources, and identify pressing needs.
The Summit was held in June 2024 (check out the website here).

title: Biologging Instrument Impact Review
text:
The first chapter of my dissertation is a broad, comprehensive review of the impacts of biologging instruments and the implications for animal welfare and data quality.
Read the preprint here.
View the minimum reporting standard for instrument characteristics here.



Figure 1. Sample instrument characteristics that would be useful to document and report with biologging manuscripts include size, mass, sensors, orientation, material, cross-sectional shape, and attachment/detachment method. Animal and data characteristics are also helpful to report.

title: Research
text:
I am interested in optimizing ecological research for scientific impact, education, and inclusion by championing on the benefits of long-term ecological studies, open science, and inclusive research practices.
Read about projects related to these topics below, or browse all projects here.

title: Research
text:
Ecology of marine predators
I’m interested in using a variety of complementary tools - particularly biologging and passive acoustic monitoring - to answer questions about remote ocean ecosystems. I have enjoyed teaching and mentoring undergraduates as a field leader at Año Nuevo State Park for the Beltran lab’s research assistant program. I have also been a teaching assistant for an upper division field class, Field Methods for Large Marine Vertebrates, in which I help guide undergraduates through the scientific process from formulating questions, to collecting data, to publishing the results.
Selected projects:
Elephant seal senescence
Seal acoustic tag

title: Research
text:
Science of science
In addition to ecological questions, I am also interested in the process of scientific discovery. Whether it’s using science facilitation practices to help research teams create new knowledge, documenting the use of open science tools, or distilling best practices from an ecological sub-field, I want to know more about the people, practices, and tools that make science happen.

title: Elephant Seal Senescence
text:
I led a class of 14 undergraduate students in designing and executing this project investigating the types of changes in elephant seal demography and behavior as they age. We found that female elephant seals experienced reproductive senescence in the form of decreased breeding probability and decreased offspring survival with advanced maternal age.
This project was published in the the Journal of Animal Ecology. Read the paper here or check out the GitHub repository here.







Breeding probability for adult female elephant seals increased up to age 11, and decreased after age 11, with the latter providing evidence for fertility senescence. Black points and error bars show the mean and 95% CI of breeding rates. Sample sizes for each age class are included above the points. Thin grey lines show the mean response for each year of the study (i.e. including the random effect of year). The thick solid lines and shaded areas show the mean response and 95% confidence interval of the fitted model, weighted by the number of seals observed in each year. The unweighted fitted model is shown by the dotted grey line. Illustrations by Alex Boersma.


I also wrote a blog post for the journal’s blog, Animal Ecology in Focus, which talks about my experience publishing the manuscript while TAing the field class.

title: EcoViz + AI
text:
I had the opportunity to work as a science facilitator for the EcoViz + AI Workshop, led by Dr. Jessica Kendall-Bar and supported by Schmidt Sciences and UC San Diego.
Together with technical facilitator Dr. Max Czapanskiy, I helped lead 30 postdocs, faculty, and technical specialists to create science communication videos, an “AI for Ecology Toolbox”, and several collaborative publications to support ecologists in using artificial intelligence.

title: Research
text:
Inclusive research practices
I believe in thinking deeply not only about my research questions, but also how that research is done. I’m passionate about creating more inclusive environments and have worked in particular on several projects to improve the safety of LGBTQ+ scientists.

Queer Ecologies, an undergraduate course in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
Queer & Trans Inclusive Field Summit
Oceanography’s Diversity Deficit, co-led with labmates Salma Abdel-Raheem and Milagros Rivera

title: Seal Acoustic Tag
text: I’m working with collaborators at Cornell to develop an instrument that can record the sounds of the deep ocean - using elephant seals as our mobile platforms! Read more about the project here.

title: Research
text:
Long term studies
Long-term studies can help answer pressing ecological questions while simultaneously creating research opportunties for early-career ecologists. I have enjoyed teaching and mentoring undergraduates as a field leader at Año Nuevo State Park for the Beltran lab’s research assistant program. I have also been a teaching assistant for an upper division field class, Field Methods for Large Marine Vertebrates, in which I help guide undergraduates through the scientific process from formulating questions, to collecting data, to publishing the results. We currently have two publications from these classes in review.

title: Seals as sentinels
text:
My advisor Dr. Roxanne Beltran and I led a class of 14 undergraduate students in designing and executing this project connecting basin-scale oceanography to elephant seal fitness, allowing us to use elephant seal success to monitor the twilight zone.
